articles.headline: Syrians Say They Are Feeling the Grip of Sanctions
articles.snippet: Measures by Turkey, the Arab League and others are already unraveling the most significant change of President Bashar al-Assad’s tenure: linking Syria to the global economy.
articles.abstract: Measures by Turkey, the Arab League and others are already unraveling the most significant change of President Bashar al-Assad’s tenure: linking Syria to the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — The walls are suddenly closing in around enterprising young Syrians who bought into the idea of a modernized economy promised by President Bashar al-Assad — their simplest money transfers are blocked, and their credit cards are useless outside Syria as the growing list of international sanctions darkens their financial future.

articles.headline: Oh, for the Good Old Days of Rude Cellphone Gabbers
articles.snippet: When virtual assistants like Apple’s Siri are used in public places, the results can be annoying, even creepy, to unwilling listeners.
articles.abstract: When virtual assistants like Apple’s Siri are used in public places, the results can be annoying, even creepy, to unwilling listeners.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is talking to a phone the same as talking on it?

articles.headline: Few Avenues for Justice in the Case Against Citi
articles.snippet: A deal between the government and Citigroup was rejected by a federal judge, who characterized the penalty as “pocket change,” but regulators may have been lucky to get what they did.
articles.abstract: A deal between the government and Citigroup was rejected by a federal judge, who characterized the penalty as “pocket change,” but regulators may have been lucky to get what they did.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is anyone going to be held legally accountable for the financial crisis? When the Securities and Exchange Commission announced recently that it was settling fraud charges against Citigroup for a paltry (for Citigroup) $285 million, the only person actually named in the S.E.C.’s charges was Brian Stoker.

articles.headline: A Credit Score That Tracks You More Closely
articles.snippet: The new measure includes data well beyond the scope of the big three credit bureaus, like your rent payments and track record on child support or alimony payments.
articles.abstract: The new measure includes data well beyond the scope of the big three credit bureaus, like your rent payments and track record on child support or alimony payments.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s no hiding now.

articles.headline: Once on Top, American Now Fights to Keep Up
articles.snippet: Other airlines have found ways to remain profitable, but American, with fewer hubs and an aging fleet, has not.
articles.abstract: Other airlines have found ways to remain profitable, but American, with fewer hubs and an aging fleet, has not.
articles.lead_paragraph: American Airlines simply couldn’t keep up.

articles.headline: A Defiant Herman Cain Suspends His Bid for Presidency
articles.snippet: The Republican candidate, whose campaign unraveled after allegations of sexual harassment and a long-term affair, said he would still advocate his tax and foreign policy plans.
articles.abstract: The Republican candidate, whose campaign unraveled after allegations of sexual harassment and a long-term affair, said he would still advocate his tax and foreign policy plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: An unapologetic and defiant Herman Cain suspended his presidential campaign on Saturday, pledging that he “would not go away” even as he abandoned the Republican presidential race in the face of escalating accusations of sexual misconduct.

articles.headline: Selling Books by Their Gilded Covers
articles.snippet: As more readers switch to e-books, publishers are releasing print books with design elements emphasizing the physical beauty of the old-fashioned hard copy.
articles.abstract: As more readers switch to e-books, publishers are releasing print books with design elements emphasizing the physical beauty of the old-fashioned hard copy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as more readers switch to the convenience of e-books, publishers are giving old-fashioned print books a makeover.

articles.headline: U.S. Agents Launder Mexican Profits of Drug Cartels
articles.snippet: D.E.A. agents have laundered millions in drug proceeds because it helps them identify how cartels move money, where they keep it and who their leaders are.
articles.abstract: D.E.A. agents have laundered millions in drug proceeds because it helps them identify how cartels move money, where they keep it and who their leaders are.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Undercover American narcotics agents have laundered or smuggled millions of dollars in drug proceeds as part of Washington’s expanding role in Mexico’s fight against drug cartels, according to current and former federal law enforcement officials.

articles.headline: Battle of the Bands (and Egos) for the Rock Hall of Fame
articles.snippet: Selection to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame can be a boon for a musician’s career. But the lobbying for votes can become intense.
articles.abstract: Selection to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame can be a boon for a musician’s career. But the lobbying for votes can become intense.
articles.lead_paragraph: OLD rock ’n’ rollers don’t fade away. They just hope for a nod from Cleveland.

articles.headline: As Gas Riches Remake Plains, Lawmaker Shares in Bounty
articles.snippet: Representative Dan Boren of Oklahoma is a champion in Washington of an industry that is experiencing a historic boom but also increasing scrutiny.
articles.abstract: Representative Dan Boren of Oklahoma is a champion in Washington of an industry that is experiencing a historic boom but also increasing scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: CALUMET, Okla. — Gas money is transforming vast stretches of Oklahoma. Here, 40 miles west of the state capital, crews work through the night drilling new wells deep into the earth, and a small army of laborers rips through just-planted fields of winter wheat to install miles of gas pipeline.

articles.headline: Secrets of the Bailout, Now Told
articles.snippet: After a new report detailing the dire situation of major banks during the financial crisis, investors can only ask: Why did it take so long to find out?
articles.abstract: After a new report detailing the dire situation of major banks during the financial crisis, investors can only ask: Why did it take so long to find out?
articles.lead_paragraph: A  FRESH account emerged last week about the magnitude of financial aid that the Federal Reserve bestowed on big banks during the 2008-09 credit crisis. The report came from Bloomberg News, which had to mount a lengthy legal fight to wrest documents from the Fed that detailed its rescue efforts.

articles.headline: Good Morning. You’re Nobel Laureates.
articles.snippet: Two quiet, celebrity-shy professors have reached the top of the economics field — with work that goes far beyond the profession’s usual labels.
articles.abstract: Two quiet, celebrity-shy professors have reached the top of the economics field — with work that goes far beyond the profession’s usual labels.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTOPHER A. SIMS, a prodigious mathematician and a path-breaking economist, was fast asleep at his home near Princeton University when the telephone rang.

articles.headline: China Signals Reluctance to Rescue E.U.
articles.snippet: Comments by a Chinese vice minister suggested that Beijing was in no hurry to help European countries finance their budget deficits.
articles.abstract: Comments by a Chinese vice minister suggested that Beijing was in no hurry to help European countries finance their budget deficits.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese government over the weekend sought to tamp down international expectations that Beijing might use its large financial reserves to help ease the European debt crisis.

articles.headline: Majority for Putin’s Party Narrows in Rebuke From Voters
articles.snippet: United Russia, the governing party of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, suffered surprisingly steep losses in parliamentary elections and was clinging to a 50 percent majority.
articles.abstract: United Russia, the governing party of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, suffered surprisingly steep losses in parliamentary elections and was clinging to a 50 percent majority.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — United Russia, the governing party of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, suffered surprisingly steep losses in parliamentary elections on Sunday and was barely clinging to a 50 percent majority, with 95 percent of the votes counted.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: New NPR Chief Faces Tough Landscape
articles.snippet: The last 14 months have been bruising for NPR, but Gary Knell, the former chief executive at Sesame Workshop, is hoping to restore order and revitalize the public radio network.
articles.abstract: The last 14 months have been bruising for NPR, but Gary Knell, the former chief executive at Sesame Workshop, is hoping to restore order and revitalize the public radio network.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Thursday, his first day as president and chief executive of NPR, Gary E. Knell took questions on Twitter and NPR’s “Talk of the Nation” — and he got an earful.

articles.headline: Investors Anticipate Clearer Picture From Europe
articles.snippet: With a series of economic meetings scheduled, investors will be looking for some signal that a solution to the Continent’s long-running debt drama is at hand.
articles.abstract: With a series of economic meetings scheduled, investors will be looking for some signal that a solution to the Continent’s long-running debt drama is at hand.
articles.lead_paragraph: After weeks of pressure from investors, European leaders won themselves a breather last week amid hopes for quick action on the debt crisis there. For the markets, the question this week is whether they can deliver.

articles.headline: Leaders Piece Together an Effort to Keep the Euro Intact
articles.snippet: European leaders are working overtime on a tentative deal to try to save the euro, which they hope to complete at a crucial summit meeting this week.
articles.abstract: European leaders are working overtime on a tentative deal to try to save the euro, which they hope to complete at a crucial summit meeting this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — European leaders are working overtime on a tentative deal to try to save the euro, which they hope to complete at a crucial summit meeting in Brussels this week. But rather than one transformative leap, the deal will have several moving parts, together meant to show resolve to protect Italy and Spain, revise the economic governance of the euro zone and prevent further debt crises, officials involved in the talks say.

articles.headline: Print Empire Embraces a New Order
articles.snippet: The announcement that Laura Lang, the head of the digital advertising agency Digitas, would be the new chief executive of Time, Inc. was a bracing moment for the print romantics among us.
articles.abstract: The announcement that Laura Lang, the head of the digital advertising agency Digitas, would be the new chief executive of Time, Inc. was a bracing moment for the print romantics among us.
articles.lead_paragraph: There have been creeping indications that the magazine business isn’t really about magazines anymore. In 2010, Hearst Magazines bought iCrossing, a digital marketing agency, and the company has since christened publications that have no print version. Every day, my in-box swells with announcements that this or that glossy now has an iPad app, nearly all of them trumpeting “amazing interactive features that take you far beyond a traditional magazine experience.” Over and over we are told that a magazine is really just one vehicle for a brand that scales across platforms.

articles.headline: Online Learning, Personalized
articles.snippet: At least 36 schools nationwide are combining teacher-led lessons with computer-based lectures and exercises using a software program based on Salman Khan’s popular YouTube lessons.
articles.abstract: At least 36 schools nationwide are combining teacher-led lessons with computer-based lectures and exercises using a software program based on Salman Khan’s popular YouTube lessons.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Jesse Roe, a ninth-grade math teacher at a charter school here called Summit, has a peephole into the brains of each of his 38 students.

articles.headline: Despite Surge, Gingrich Faces Major Hurdles
articles.snippet: If neither Newt Gingrich nor Mitt Romney locks up the nomination early, Mr. Gingrich might need to survive a war of attrition of the sort for which he is unprepared at the moment.
articles.abstract: If neither Newt Gingrich nor Mitt Romney locks up the nomination early, Mr. Gingrich might need to survive a war of attrition of the sort for which he is unprepared at the moment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Surging in polls is one thing. But as Newt Gingrich seeks to turn his impressive performance in surveys into votes, he is scrambling madly to build the kind of organization that Mitt Romney has methodically put in place for a year, one that will let him compete through all 50 contests, often in multiple states at once.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Xbox Live Challenges Cable Box
articles.snippet: Beginning Tuesday, subscribers of Microsoft’s Xbox Live online service will be able to watch a wide array of mainstream television programming from the Xbox 360 console.
articles.abstract: Beginning Tuesday, subscribers of Microsoft’s Xbox Live online service will be able to watch a wide array of mainstream television programming from the Xbox 360 console.
articles.lead_paragraph: The old-fashioned cable television set-top box — long the hub of living-room entertainment for most people — is about to become less relevant.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Sarkozy and Merkel Push for Changes to Europe Treaty
articles.snippet: The leaders of France and Germany met Monday and agreed to propose treaty changes to promote more fiscal discipline, including a limit on budget deficits.
articles.abstract: The leaders of France and Germany met Monday and agreed to propose treaty changes to promote more fiscal discipline, including a limit on budget deficits.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Under the pressure of financial crisis and with the euro currency at stake, the two main leaders of the euro zone said Monday that they would together push to remake the European Union into a more integrated political and economic federation, with tight legal restraints on how much debt national parliaments can issue.
